RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

R. SNELLING
PRICE: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF,
THURSDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1905.
CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.

A great deal of interest has been taken in Egypt since the last Anglo-French agreement removed many of the fears that prevented investors from exploiting the country to the full extent of its possibilities, and several important undertakings have been launched during the past eighteen months, chiefly for the purpose of acquiring land and other real estate concessions. The first annual statements of these ventures are now beginning to appear, and erstwhile we noted the publication of the initial report of the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company. Last week was issued the first report of the Corporation of Western Egypt, a concern which was floated early this year, and holds concessions entitling it, amongst other things, to take up during the course of the next three decades some 600,000 feddans of land (a feddan being roughly an acre) in the cases of Khargs, Dakhla, Farafra and Baharia. The report covers the period to 30th September last, and shows that the Corporation is in a very strong financial position. Of its £500,000 capital about £250,000 has been subscribed and £215,600 paid up, the final call of 5s. per share having been postponed because the Directors already possess for the time being sufficient money for working purposes. Although over £110,000 has been spent on preliminary operations, plant, etc., £98,000 is still in hand, either in the shape of cash or easily realised firstclass securities. The particulars given in the report make a good showing as a return for the expenditures so far incurred. Kharga and the other oases mentioned will not be familiar names to the majority of people, and it will suffice to say that they represent a territory of about £74,000 square miles, inhabited by a population of about 30,000 : that they lie about 300 miles from Cairo, off the Nile valley, and that by a branch line now in course of construction and joining the State Railways at Farshut, they will be brought into direct communication with the capital. A detailed survey of a considerable portion of Central Kharga has been made during the past season, and the cultivable areas of some x00 square kilometrees have been determined and mapped out. The whole of the railway route has been surveyed, and, as already stated, the construction of the line has commenced, and even the contracts have been placed for the rolling stock. One of the most satisfactory results of the development work is that which has determined the adequacy of the water supply, a point of primary importance in a venture of this kind in such a country as Egypt. Boring operations both on the Kharga and Dakhla oases have demonstrated a full artesian supply, and have satisfied the corporation's local manager and geological expert that the yield is practically inexhaustible. That the supply must be of extraordinary permanence is proved by the fact that old wells sunk by the Romans and ancient Egyptians, when reopened, still pour out over 500 gallons a minute.

Given a good water supply for irrigation, the successful development of the land is practically assured, other things being equal. This development has naturally had a chief claim on the attention of the Directors, and it is to promote it that communication is being established as rapidly as possible with the State Railways. This connection will not only assist in the exploitation of the oases, but must necessarily thereby be a determining factor in the value of the land. The worth of land is rising throughout Egypt generally, as Land Cromer had occasion to point out in his last report ; and thought the Directors have already had applications for claims they are waiting to see what effect the completion of the first section of the railway will have in increasing the value of their estates before striking an approximate maximum price for purchasers. The Directors state that on present data they think £20 per feddan ought to be obtained in the neighborhood of the line and £10 per feddan in the more remote districts. Taking an average of only £12 10s per feddan for the 20,000 feddans the corporation is entitled to exploit per annum, the gross revenue from this source alone would be £250,000. The land is of loamy clay, similar to that already cultivated and yielding excellent crops of cereals, dates, etc. ; but the corporation's experts are making an exhaustive study of the local conditions to determine whether cotton and other staples can also be profitably grown. The land business, however, great as it is, is by no means the only interest of the corporation. Its concessions carry mineral and other rights, and their exploitation, it is hoped, will contribute to the general success of the undertaking. At present, for obvious reasons, attention to this side of the corporation's prospects has been rather restricted in scope, but enough has been accomplished to show that the mineral possibilities are far from unpromising. An expert who has been examining the earthy minerals, such as alum, ochres and salts of manganese and cobalt, states that, pending a full analysis, he has no hesitation in asserting that their potential value is commercially very great. Aluminous deposits of vast extent have already been disclosed at Kharga, and are to be worked for aluminium sulphate by a process of manufacture that can be undertaken by the natives alone. These particulars serve to show the large sphere of operations covered by the corporation, and if the rapid progress made during the present year be maintained, there should be much additional matter of interest for the shareholders in the next annual report.

div.head: TSAR’S ARMY FAITHFUL.
WITTE NOT TO RESIGN.
RUSSIAN FINANCES SOUND
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service).
London, December 14.

Count Witte declares that the Russian army is still faithful to the Tsar, in spite of the many mutinies which have broken out. The finances of the country are, he states, perfectly sound, and he asserts that the interest on the Russian bonds will be faithfully and punctually paid. Count Witte adds that he has no intention whatever of resigning.

div.head: PLOT AGAINST THE TSAR.
WORK OF ZEMSTVOS.
div.p: St. Petersburg. December 13.
Governors of provinces and districts where until now martial law has not been enforced have been invested with practically dictatorial powers for three months.
(Reuter)
Warsaw, December 13.
The police in the first arrondissement have gone on strike.
It is rumoured that the Zemstvos have plotted to overthrow the Tsar in favor of a constitutional monarch.
(Havas)

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORM SCHEME.
THE PORTE’S REPLY.
div.p: Paris, December 13.

In its reply the Porte accepts the financial regulation of Macedonia and makes reserves concerning the military budget, based on a previous arrangement with the Ottoman Bank approved by the Ambassadors.
(Havas)

div.head: GREAT BRITAIN AND GERMANY.
COMMERCIAL ARRANGEMENT.
div.p: Berlin, December 13.
The Reichstag has agreed to the extension of the provisional commercial arrangement with Great Britain.
(Reuter)

div.head: DEATH OF BRITISH GENERAL.
div.p: London, December 13.
General Robert Younghusband is dead.
(Reuter)

The late General Robert Romer Younghus-band was born in 1819, and entered the army in 1837, being made General in 1877. He served in Scinde and Beloochistan in 1840-42 and was with the Light Battalion at Candahar. He was Brigade-Major in the battles of Meanee and Hyderabad from 1843-48 and of the Raj-pootana Field Force, 1852-54. He was Assistant Adjutant General at Scinde from 1854 to 1856 and Deputy Adjutant General, Persian Expeditionary Force, from 1856 to 1857 (medal with clasp and C.B.). From 1862 to 1866 he was Brigadier-General commanding at Nusse-rabad.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Conservatoire of Music.
The committee of the Alexandria Conservatoire have decided on opening a singing class for young girls in the morning.
Khedive's Accession Fetes.
The subscriptions collected for the celebration of the anniversary of the Khedive’s accession now amount to L E. 565.
American Mission.
Ismail Bey Asem, the Cairo advocate, will speak on the subject of temperance at the American Mission church to-night at 8 o’clock.
Kasr-el-Nil Bridge.
From Friday, 15th inst, and until further notice the Kasr el Nil Bridge will be open to navigation and closed to traffic from 1.30 to 3 p.m.
Execution.
A nonogenarian criminal will be executed in a few days time. Mohamed Aboa El Ghali, such is his name, is 90 years of age and was found guilty of poisoning five of his nephews and nieces.
National Hotel.

Every Friday afternoon during the season, the band of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, under the bA on of Mr. R. Watson Ramsey, will perform a programme of music on the terrace of this hotel from 4 to 6 p.m.
Sanitary Dept.

MM. Charles Vermeulen, Herbert Bill Han-son, Max Zaccar and Abdallah Y. Meraeb, physicians Dimitri Comanios, pharmacist, and. Wahiba Mohamed, Bamba Said and Lambrini Phlokioti, midwives, have been authorized to practise in Egypt.
All Saints', Ramleh.

A vocal and instrumental concert will be held on Friday, 29th inst., at 9 p.m, in the Parish Room, the Parsonage, Bulkeley, in aid of church expenses of All Saints,' Ramleh. The following have kindly offered their assistance : Messrs. M. A. Ruffer, Ehrlich and Artelli, Mr-. Edward Miss, Miss Violet Alderson, Miss Harden, and Mr. H.V. Hall. In addition, Lira Lehmann’s song-cycle, entitled "The Daisy Chain," will be given by the following ladies and gentlemen : Mrs W. R. Williams. Miss Carver, Mr. J. Purvis, and Rev. R. F Rynd. Tickets, P.T. 20 each (no reserved seats), can be obtained from F. Mellor and Co., Old Bourse Street, Alexandria, and D. Stein and Co. (near tram station), Bulkeley, or from the clergy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Auguste and Prince Pierre d’Aren-berg, with Count de Choiseul, Coant de Se-rionne, and M. Tillier, left Port Said for Ismailia on Tuesday. The party will stay a few days at Ismailia before leaving for Mombasa and Lake Victoria.
The Earl and Countess of Carnarvon are to spend a few weeks in Egypt in the New Year, and will leave Marseilles on January 12.
Sir Malcolm Mollwraith arrived at Assiout on Tuesday and opened his inspection of the native tribunals yesterday.
Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, is leaving England for Egypt on the 21st inst.
Among the latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel are Sir William and Lady Goulding. Sir William is the Chairman of the Great Southern and Western Railway of Ireland.
Mr. W. R. Bousfield, KC., M.P , contra dicta the statement that he is going for a tour in Greece and Egypt next spring.

Herr Kehren, who has been till now attached to the German Consulate at Antwerp, has been appointed Vice Consul at Cairo, to replace Dr. Rhomberg, who has been transferred to Barcelona. Herr Kehren is expected to arrive towards the end of the month.

Mr. Wells, Chief Inspector of Mines to the Ministry of Finance, has left for Edfon with Mr. Mitchell Innes. The Undersecretary of State for Finance will accompany Mr. Wells on a ten days’ inspecting trip in the mining districts between the Nile and the Red Sea.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel editor of "Al Lewa," has been admitted as "Stagiaire” at the Cairo Mixed Bar by the Mixed Court of Appeal.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Comte de Miramon, Comtesse de Miramon, Mr. H. C. Bryant, Mr. and Mrs. Chanter, Mr. Mitcheson, Mr. and Mme Stenapholi, Frl Huffner, Frl. von Carls brog, Mr. H. Broadhurst, Crook shank Pasha. Bimbashi Edgeworth, B.A., Lady Nesta Fitz-Gerald, Mr. Meredith, Mr. Star, Mr. Christian and party, Mr. Hanna.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said are Mr. M. Kar-minski, Mr. W. R, B. Briscoe, Mr. R, S. Nicholson, Mr. G. W. Parker, Miss J. Smith, Mr. H. Whiteside, Mrs. Whiteside, Mr. W. Wilson, Mrs. Wilson. Purvis Bey, M. G. Pellegrini, the New Italian Vice-Consul at Port-Said, Mr. C. T. Morris, and Mr. A. Eaman.

div.head: GOLD IN EGYPT.
THE RECENT IMPORTANT FINDS.
div.p: The recent discovery of gold in the western oases is of the first importance not only to the interests of the Corporation of Western Egypt but to the general development of the mining industry of the country. It affords a first indication of the actual direction in which the gold has drifted that must have been eroded from the eastern hills daring vast geological periods before man appeared in the Nile Valley, and also of the probable manner of its deposition.

So far as the immediate interests of the Corporation are concerned,2 dwts. per ton may not seem, at first sight, to be very important; but it is to be remembered that the gold is contained in pyrites which form generally more than one-tenth of the phosphate rook. This rook must in any case be powdered to be commercially useful, and when this is done the pyrites can be separated with very little expense, while the richness and commercial value of the phosphates are greatly enhanced by its removal.

The separated pyrites should then carry from half an ounce to an ounce per ton. and will be valuable as a source of sulphur and sulphuric acid, in addition to yielding this amount of gold. It will also be necessary to enquire what has become of the gold that has weathered out of the extensive phosphate outcrops since the oases were first formed or since their formation commenced.

It is impossible to say at present exactly where it may be found, but it is at least permissible to hope that it is held within the oases area. Another point to be considered is what indication this discovery may give to aid in tracing and discovering the “deep leads” which very possibly exist between the gold belts of the Eastern hills and the oases. The discovery of such leads would give a new impulse to Egyptian mining, and might result in most important developments.

div.head: ASSOUAN RESERVOIR.
div.p: The adjudication on tenders for.the protec-tive works downstream of the looks at Assouan Reservoir has been settled in favor of the following contractors : —
L.E. Urquhart and Williamson .... 4.889 G. Mitchell and Mohamed Ibrahim . . 8,033 G. H. West............................6,722 W. H. Williamson...................... 3 350
The tender of Messrs. Urqnhart and William-son for the supply of atone facings in hewn granite for the talus works downstream of the looks at Assouan Reservoir baa been accepted. It is for LE 10,200.

The above works are the result of 8ir Benjamin Baker's visit last season. Whenhe visited the work last winter, he recommended extensive protective works on the talus downstream of the dam, where the severe action of the water through he sluices had eroded even the sound granite. The P. W. D. had recognised the necessity of these protective works and had already commenced them, and had in 1901 completed the repairs of certain of the worst places, and were intending to spend a further sum of L.E 50,000 in 1905. Sir Benjamin, however, recommended protective works upon a still larger scale than this, which will involve an expenditure of something like a quarter of a million of money, and take two years to complete.

div.head: EXPEDITION FOR STUDYING THE NILE CATARACTS.
div.p: It has been decided to make a complete and detailed survey of the Nile cataracts, south of Wady-Halfa, and to study the possibility of constructing another dam and reservoir , somewhere to the south of the existing one. Such a supplementary work will probably be necessary, under any circumstances, even should the Assouan dam be raised, as the future wants of Egypt will necessitate a very large amount of water being stored, In any work of the kind, constructed south of Wady-Halfa, a navigation channel and looks may be omitted, as, with the railway from Wady-Halfa to Khartoum, no through river traffic is likely to arise, more especially as, on this reach of the river, it must always be difficult and dangerous, and only possible during flood.
The survey parties commenced work this autumn.

div.head: CAMPING OUT IN EGYPT.
div.p: There is some probability of the neighbourhood of the Ghizeh pyramids becoming a favorite site for a residential European tent dwelling colony. The Public Security Department of the Ministry of the Interior has determined that these squatters should not be permitted to pitch their tents there just as they please, and a notice has been issued wherein it is stated that it is forbidden to erect tents in the vicinity of the Ghizeh pyramids without a permit from the Ministry of tbs Interior.

Applications for such permits most be addressed to the Minister of the Interior. The name and surname of the Applicant, nationality, occupation and residence, together. with the number of tents, the site on which they are to be erected, and the period for which the permit is required, must be mentioned in the application.
This regulation is also to apply to the erection of tents in the neighbourhood of monuments of the past at Assouan.

div.head: QUIET AT ALEXANDRIA.
ACTION OF AUTHORITIES.
div.p: Yesterday no incident occurred at Alexandria to disturb public security, but the state of mind of a large portion of the European population is by no means tranquil. As an example of this feeling of insecurity we may instance the run on the shops of the gunsmiths yesterday. The police authorities thought that yesterday the panic had to all appearances so much subsided that it would be permissible to allow the gunsmiths' establishments to be reopened. But as soon as the decision of the authorities became known, there was a great rush to buy arms on the part of Europeans and a big trade was done in revolvers end other weapons. The authorities decided therefore to again order the closing of these shops, and this morning all of the gunsmiths were shut up and will remain so until further notice.

The police authorities ere quite satisfied that the attitude of the natives is peaceful, and they are in fact quite cowed. But the authorities state that they are afraid of the Europeans in their present excited state, and believe that if there is any renewal of the disturbance it will be provoked by the Europeans.

Morice Bey, Inspector of the Parquet at the Ministry of Justice, has arrived from Cairo in connection with the forthcoming trials of the persons accused of having taken part in the riot on Sunday afternoon.

Up to now no death has occurred among the Europeans and natives injured in the disorders. Mr. Marsden, the sub-manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, is recovering from his wound, and will in all probability be able to resume his duties next week.
CONVOCATION OF SHEIKHS.

This morning and yesterday afternoon there were two important meetings of all the religious sheikha, who are accustomed to preach in the mosques at Alexandria. These meetings were convened by the order of Mahmoud Pasha 8idky, Governor of Alexandria, and all who were summoned attended. The Governor addressed the sheikhs on the subject of the recent disturbance and laid strict injunctions upon them all to use their best endeavours in their religious addresses to impress upon their hearers the need for calmness, as unless the populace preserved its self-control public security would again be disturbed. His Excellency's earnest exhortations had a great effect on his audience and all the sheikhs present this morning and at yesterday's meeting promised the Governor that they would be untiring in their efforts to use their religious influence in the interests of public tranquillity.
EUROPEAN CLERICAL INFLUENCE

His Holiness Photius, the Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, has informed the Governor that he will in his sermon on Sunday next dwell upon the necessity of peace and harmony between the Orthodox Greek population and the natives. His Holiness has also enjoined the Orthodox clergy throughout Alexandria , to endeavour to pacify any excitement among members of their congregations.
The Latin Archbishop of Alexandria has also undertaken to use his influence in the same direction.
FEARS FOR THE FUTURE.

Nervous people have been considerably alarmed by the very widespread rumours as to a forthcoming renewal of the disturbance which it is alleged has been timed to take place on Sunday next But the authorities are fully prepared for any such renewal of the troubles and all precautions have been taken to prevent any disorders again breaking out so there is not the slightest need for any alarm.
TELEGRAM FROM MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL
The following telegram was received by us yesterday, too late for inclusion in our issue of that day:--

Please read what I have written in the "Reforme" yesterday, so that yon may know that I had always preached the harmony of the.Eyptians and the Europeans residents, and that the accusing of the Egyptians and the leaders of the public opinion in Egypt with fanatism is an absurd thing which promotes discord and dissension. I believe that the difference in political opinions does not tend to instigate the holders of such opinions to accuse themselves injustly. I see that the interest of my country lies in the preservance of peace and tranquillity. No one can say that I have said or done the reverse. I affected that you will turn a deaf ear to the fabricated and alarming reports promoted by the alarmists for personal prejudices and especial designs and to interpret with great care what is published in the Mohamedan newspapers about the Macedonian crisis before giving any decision about their attitude. Had you done so you would have seen that the "Al Lewa” is the mildest and most of all in exerting efforts to cultivate agreement between the different nationalities in Egypt I am much astonished for yon have not written any blaming word to the foreign rabbles who were the cause of the Alexandrian disturbance. I believe that the only remedy to such inconveniences is the allowing the Mixed Tribunals to settle criminal cases committed by or against the foreigners for it is the only thing which preserves the public security,—Mustapha Kamel Pasha.

div.head: LAST SUNDAY'S RIOT.
CORRESPONDENT’S VIEWS
div.p: A well-known resident at Alexandria writes:—I would express the view, if you will kindly permit me to do so through you, that it would be safer not to belittle last Sunday’s disturbances. It is quite possible that had your paper been rather more of an alarmist, you might have moved the authorities to have been bettor prepared, and that, as a consequence, last Sunday’s riot would have been suppressed with such promptitude and energy as to have justified you in assuring the public now that no repetition of such recurrences need be feared. As it is, rumour has it, in spite of everything that the papers say, that next Sunday is to be the witness of a far more grave state of things than last Sunday was, and this is repeated with such assurance by so many months that many people are becoming seriously alarmed. Of what use is it to be satisfied to merely state that there is no farther occasion for alarm and to make other such like statements, as the papers are now doing. These statements do not reassure people in the least, they are simply a repeti tion of those made in 1882. What people want to know is what precautions are being taken by the authorities against a repetition of Sunday’s disturbances. They want to see there mentioned by newspapers, such as your own, after due enquiry has been made. They want to learn if it is. intended to deal severely and promptly with all disturbers' of the peace, and, if so, they want such intentions to be made generally known. They want to know if such enquiries are being made as to the original cause of last Sunday’s rioting as will lead to the detection of the persons responsible for the feeling which caused a mere gambling quarrel to assume the proportions it did. They want aall this to be mads generally known in order not only to judge if tranquillity has really been assured for the present, but to serve as a lesson to persons interested in creating discord and riot that their acts, however carefully hidden, will be certainly traced and brought home to them with the utmost severity.

The foregoing, I venture to submit, will do more to allay toe fears of nervous people than mere assurance and pooh-poohing the gravity of what has taken place. It is quite correct to reassure our visitors the tourists, but residents who are in continual touch with the natives' and know what is really going on also require some consideration, and mere state menu that all is now quiet will hardly satisfy them. The natives themselves, those who desire law and order, require to be reassured also ; they are far from being so at present Many of my native friends openly tell me they are much afraid of farther disturbances business is also affected by the present state of things. As to the villages, I fear that unless the authorities show a firm hand and the intention to use most severe measures there may be trouble there also.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: The disturbance on Sunday has led to a discussion of the part the Capitulations played as a secondary cause.
"Al Moayad" is of opinion that the Capitula-tions are greatly to be blamed for the outbreak at Alexandria, and it urges the Government to prevent Europeans from carrying arms.

"Al Abram" says that the English want to use the disturbance as a lever to obtain more power than before, and both "Al Lewa” and "Al Ahram” claim that the Mixed Courts should be made competent in the case of European criminals. His view is opposed to that of Lord Cromer, who states in his last Report that "‘The proposal to transfer criminal jurisdiction over Europeans from the consular to the Mixed Courts is not one which the British Government could, under present circumstances , view with favor, nor one which they could advise the Egyptian Government to accept."

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: There have been many rumours since Sunday as to an approaching increase in the strength of the Army of Occupation, especially as regards the garrison at Alexandria. We have, however, been unable to obtain any official confirmation of these rumours.

div.head: ST. MARK’S AND ALL SAINTS
div.p: The Rev. A. H. Longley, B. A., late mathematical scholar of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, now chaplain in St George's Collegiate Church, Jerusalem, has accepted the post of assistant chaplain and will leave for Alexandria at the end of this month.
The Rev. R. Wormell has accepted from the India Office a chaplaincy in the Bombay Ecclesiastical Establishment.
Algernon Ward.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The M.M. steamer Portugal arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday morning.
The S.S.. Egyptian (Westcott and Lauranoe Line) left Malta yesterday and is doe here next Sunday, with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The S.S. Bloemfontein (Westcott and Lau-rance Line) left Malta yesterday and is due here Sunday next with general cargo from Antwerp and London, and coals from New castle.

div.head: THE KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
10% DIVIDEND DECLARED.
div.p: The directors-ofthe Khedivial Mail Steam ship and Graving Dock Company, Limited, will present a very satisfactory report at the -eighth ordinary general meeting of the share- holders which is to he held to-morrow at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, EC.

The statement of accounts for the year ending 30th of June last is as follows:--The trading profit for the year, including Government subsidies, and after charging insurance of steamers, all salaries, office and general expenses, has amounted to 76,985,17.7, to which is added for transfer fees £2,12.6, making together £76,988.10.2. From which is deducted : D benture interest, depreciation, directors’ and auditors' remuneration, £18,875.10.0, leaving a balance of £58,113.0.1. The balance brought forward from the previous year is £2,228.18.6, making a total of £60,841.18.7. Of this sum dividends have been paid on the Preference shares for two-and-a half years to 31st December , 1904, amounting to £37,491.9.6, leaving a balance of £32,850.9.1. A farther dividend on Preference shares for the half-year ending 30th June last was paid on September 30th, amounting to £ 1,497.16.0, leaving a balance available for appropriation of £27,352.13.1.

The directors now recommend the payment of a dividend at the rate of 10 per cent, on the Ordinary shares, payable on December 31st, which would absorb £10,000.0.0, leaving a balance to be carried forward to next account of £17,352.13.1.
The directors are pleased to report that doting the past year the vessels have been well kept up. They have run free from any serious accidents, and all services have been regularly maintained.

Owing to the increased volume of business the directors have contracted with Messrs. Swan, Hunter and Wigham Richardson, Limited, for a new passenger steamer, with all modern improvements, and calculated to maintain speed of from 17 to 18 knots at sea. The directors hope that the new vessel will be a profitable acquisition to the company's fleet, She is to be finished and delivered in July next. Since the close of last year, two vessels, the Keneh, of 1,581 tons, and the Kosseir, of 1,851. tons, have been purchased and added to the company’s fleet.

To meet the requirements of the Egyptian authorities, a regular direct service has been established between Suez and Suakin in connection with the new railway, Suakin to Khartoum. Under an agreement with the Egyptian Government a subsidy of £5,000 per annum (for five years) will be paid to the company in consideration of its services in regard to this line.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The Legislative Council meets today to consider the draft Budget for 1906 and the attached note of the Committee of Finance, which it will then transmit to the Council of Ministers.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: It is always difficult for a single artist to hold the attention of his audience throughout the programme, and M. Pierre Loredan has to be congratulated on the very excellent recital he gave at the Savoy yesterday afternoon. It is only to be regretted that his concert had not been more widely advertised, for though he early claimed the sympathies of his audience the hall was never really full. M. Pierre Loredan plays with much taste and subtle feeling, and his execution is excellent. He gave a very fine rendering of Mendelssohn's "Rondo capriccioso,” and Chopin’s "Beroeuse” was a delightful achievement. His "Il Tremolo,” by Gottsohalk, was excellent is every way, his phrasing of the highest order. Perhaps it was the length of the performance or a slight want of sympathy that prevented his doing full justice to Raff's "Fileuse,” for his rendering of that delicate "Gazouillement du printemps” by Sinding had been particularly graceful and happy.

div.head: HELOUAN.
div.p: The Tewfik Palace Hotel have inaugurated this season a fortnightly trip by river to the Barrage. The launches used on these trips belong to the Anglo-American Nile 8teamer and Hotel Company, and passengers are conveyed from the hotel to the river, where the launches await them. Lunch and tea are to be had on board, but on the return journey passengers will be landed at the Kasr-el-Nil Bridge in order that they may arrive back at Helouan in time for dinner. The first trip was made yesterday, and the next one is arranged for Wednesday, 27th inst.

Mr. Hergel, who has contributed during the past two years by no means a small part towards the rising popularity of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, distinguishes himself as manager by giving an excellent cuisine, so as to content the most refined epicures. His object is to combine the advantageous position of the hotel with an excellent table, and we can only say he quite realises his ambition and thereby con-siderably adds to the inner comforts of those choosing the late Khedive's Palace as a winter resort.
The office of Messrs. Cumming and Calleja have been removed to the 2nd floor of No. 2, Sursock Buildings, Old Bouse Street, behind the Eastern Telegraph Co.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL NOTES. M. CAPART'S WORK.
div.p: The second volume of the magnificent work "Recueil de Monumnets Egyptiens," of Monsieur Jean Capart, conservator of the Egyptian Museum in Brussels, containing a further fifty heliogravare reproductions of Egyptian antiquities, has just been published by M. Vromant. The monuments selected for this series are fully as important and interesting as those of the first volume, the photographs are as carefully prepared, and the accompanying dissertation upon each precisely what is adequate. This time almost every hieroglyphic text upon the objects is fully set forth in the essay referring to it, and generally translated, so that the work is useful for students of Egypt as well as for the history of Egyptian art.

As with the previous subjects selected, these are from collections generally not in the large museums of European Capitals but in less visited places, and many of the new plates reproduce relics at Athens, Brussels, Marseilles, and University College, London. As far as convenient the chronological order is followed in the arrangement of the plates, the series commencing with the 4th dynasty and terminating with a Byzantine tapestry. In reviewing such a valuable work it is difficult to decide upon which of the heliogravures to especially comment upon, but there are a certain number of them which to an Egyptologist are peculiarly noteworthy. Of these plate 55, giving a statue of marvellously fine workmanship yet dating as early perhaps as the 5th dynasty, is specially interesting. The features are well preserved and the head surmounted with a peculiar perruque, or wig, the plaits of which in front are short, ending in the crown of the cranium, fresh ones commencing there and falling down at the back to the neck. The waist cloth is pleeted upon the right side of the body only. The pose of the body is precisely that of the familiar later type of Egyptian human statues, but the porportions of the figure are those of adolescence, the arms and legs being thin and the general attitude not so rigid.

Plate 59 is a photograph of the Sphinx with human head, now in Louvre, and supposed to have come from Tarsis. Although the head is somewhat mutilated sufficient of the facial carving remains to show that it is of similar physiognomy to the other celebrated Sphinx from the same site which in an inscription upon it bore the name of Apepi, the Hyksos, or Shepherd king. It was upon the features of this second human-headed Sphinx that many theories of the ethnic affinities of the Hyksos were founded, until a Russian Egyptologist, M. Golenischoff, proved that not only was the Apepi text not the only one upon the statue, for it bore the name of Pisebkhenon of the 21st dynasty and that the latter's cartouche had been graven over an erasure of some other Pharaoh's name, but that the king whose features it originally represented was Amenemhat III., inscribed with his name, at St. Petersburg, and of another similar statuette evidently of the same personage, but without any inscription. The proof of identity and date of production of the personage and monument, is not only derived from the visage, but from the peculiar rayed headdress and also ibbed, or striated shoulder covering. The Louvre sphinx bears texts of Rameses II., and his son, Menepthas, inscribed over erasures of those of previous owners. Nothing in Egyptian royal manners was, unfortunately, more de rigeur than to remove the record of a previous Pharaoh from some valuable monument and substitute another.

The Hyksos king may not have been the culprit in the case of the best preserved of the Tanis sphinxes who thus wronged Amenemhat, but the deed may have been done by orders of Pisebkhenon, whose cartouche placed upon the breast has usurped the site where the original text was carved. The Apepi name upon that sphinx is engraved on the shoulder, a Semitic practice alluded to in the phrase "the Government shall be upon his shoulders." If the Hyksos origin of these Tanis sphinxes and that of the similar typed specimen from Bubastis has to be abandoned, all the voluminous essays upon the racial connection of that mysterious people based upon them become worthless. The idea was apparently fortified by the town of Tarris, whence the earliest found sphinxes came, having been the Hyksos capital ; but other specimens, possessing similar peculiarities, have been discovered at Bubastis, and also up the Nile at El Kah, a site no Hyksos, save as a prisoner, ever saw, whilst it formed part of Amenemhat III's kingdom. Why the features of the 12th dynasty monarchy differed so much from those of other Egyptian sovereigns is as yet undetermined.

For the next subject M. Capart has selected a head in the Egyptian collection at University College, London, because it provides another portrait of Amenemhat II. Unfortunately, the nose is partly broken away. It, however, still remains a splendid specimen of Egyptian sculptures, and is perhaps the most important phototype in this volume. It of course presents the same type of rayed head dress, but in the case the remarkable arrangement of the rays in groups of three is very manifest. Herr Borchardt believes this design to be a peculiarity entirely of 12th dynasty Pharaonic statues and almost so of those solely of Amenemhat II. As we are unable to illustrate those notes by the head in question it will be well to quote.

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL COLLISION. CLAIM FOR DAMAGES.
div.p: The collision of the S.S. Chathan and its subsequent blowing up in the Suez Canal formed the subject of a claim by the owners of the vessel against the owners of the Clan Cumming before the president and the Trinity Masters in the Admiralty Court last week.

It appeared that on Sept. 5 of this year, shortly after seven p.m., the Chatham lay in the Suez Canal on a voyage from London and the Elbe to Bangkok and Yokohama, having on board a cargo which included 3600 cases of dynamite and sixteen cases of detonators. The vessel stood near the eastern bank, about a cable to the north of the tenth mile-post. The weather was fine and clear, with a light wind blowing and the Clan Cumming came easily along at about five miles an hour, bound for Port Said. As she approached the Chatham she opened her masthead and both side lights, and when the two vessels were about 1 1/2 mile distant from each other measures were taken for the purpose of tying up the Chathan to allow the Clan Cumming to pass. Engines were put to slow, dead slow, and then stopped. When from a quarter to half a mile away the defendant's vessel, so the plaintiffs allege, approached at a high rate of speed, and did not open her red light until a very short distance off. When collision seemed imminent she sounded three short blasts on the whistle, and immediately afterwards her stem struck the starboard bow of the Chatham. It was a violent blow, cutting right into the forecastle. The force of the collision cut down the bulkhead of the Chatham causing the lamp attached to it to fall and set fire to the contents of the forecastle. It became necessary to flood the forehold and submerge the vessel in order to prevent the fire spreading to the explosives on board. The Chatham was subsequently blown up by order of the Canal authorities. Plaintiffs alleged that the Clan Cumming was handled improperly, nd that a good look-out was not kept. They therefore claimed judgement against the defendants and their bail for the damage caused to the plaintiffs by reason of the collision ; also a reference to the Regustrar, assisted by merchants, to assess the amount of the damage.

The defence was that lights were burning brightly on the Clan Cumming, and a good look-out was also being kept. The egines were, on the approach, put at half-speed, slowed down, and then stopped. Almost immediately afterwards the engines of the Clan Cumming were put full-speed astern and three loud blasts were sounded on the whistle, but the Chatham, which was heard to let go her starboard anchor and to sound a blast, was seen to extinguish her lights, and although the port anchor of the Clan Cumming was let go and held on to, the Chatham, it was alleged, came on with considerable headway, and with her starboard bow struck the stem of the Clan Cumming, inflicting considerable damage. Defendants denied the allegations of improper handling, and counterclaimed against the plaintiffs for damages in respect of the collision.
Mr. Laing, K. C., Mr. Scrutton, K. C., and Mr. Dumas appeared for the plaintiffs ; and the defendants were represented by Mr. Pickford, K. C., Mr. Butler Aspinall, K. C., and Mr. Bullock.

Mr. Pickford, answering his lordship, said the real point was on the question of speed. The rate at which the Chatham was travelling was, in his opinion, excessive, having regard to the regulations of the canal.
Sir Gorell Barnes : What do you say was the speed of the Clan Cumming?
Mr. Pickford : Regulation speed, of course.
Witnesses were being called for the plaintiffs when the Court adjourned.

M. Maspero's description of the features of this monarch in reference to a statue supposed to represent him :

"Certes, il a la figure ronde et pleine de " Amenemhat (ou d'Ousirtasen I) et l'air de " famille est indeniable entre ses traits et ceux " de ses ancetres ; mais on devine, des le pre- " mier coup d'oeil, que l'artiste n'a rien fait " pour flatter son modele. Le front est bas, un " peu fuyant, serre aux tempes, le nez vigou- " reux, aique, large du haut, la bouche epaisse " et dedaigneuse presse les levres et s'abaises " aux coins comme pour eviter le sourire fami- " lier au commun des statues egyptiennes, le " menton lourd et charnu pointe en avant...; " les yeux sont petits, etroite, clos de fortes " paupieres ; les pommettes sont osseuses, " proeminentes ; les joues se creusent ; les " muscles, qui cernent le nez et la bouche, " s'accusent puissamment."

M. Capart's book, for which the moderate price of 25 francs only is charged, will, it is to be hoped, be widely circulated ; the present edition, however, being limited to 200 copies, early application to secure one is necessary. Now that he is on a visit to Egypt it is to be hoped he will obtain success to private collections here and find therein ample material for a third volume.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIGHT RAILWAYS. REPORT OF INSPECTOR.
div.p: An interesting report on the working of light railways throughout Egypt during the past year has been made by Mr. Gunn, of the Railway Administration. We extract the following passages :--

There has been added to the lines only 97 kilometres in all and a section of 10 kilometres closed, making an actual increase of 17 kilometres for the year, giving a total of 1,107 kilometres for all three companies as compared with 1,090 for the previous year. 15 kilometres have been opened since the close of the companies' years by the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Co., and they are constructing several other sections.

The total receipts of the three systems amounted to L.E. 171,067 for the previous year. It will be seen by these figures that there is an increase of thirty-eight thousand and eleven Egyptian pounds (L.E. 38,011) of which sum L.E. 29,762 belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Co.

The total number of passengers carried was over 5 3/4 millions (5,797,562), an increase over the previous year of over one million. Of this total the Delta Co. carried nearly 4 1/2 millions (4,478,403). Goods, 979,554 tons lifted, as against 642,969 for 1903, showing an increase of 327,585. This includes the transport of 195,195 tons of earth for reclaiming land by the Delta Co. While the kilometrage practically remains the same, the gross receipts show an increase on the total of L.E. 171,067 for 1903 equal to 22%. To this increase more than half is due to the passenger traffic, viz.: L.E. 9,113. While the cotton crop was good and contributed to the great increase over the last year, it is evident that a large factor has been the through-booking with the Government Railways. Shippers are beginning to find out that they can ship their goods to almost any part of the country while remaining themselves at home, and are availing themselves of it. It does not, however, seem to be generally known. I should like to call attention to the fact that it is highly desirable to have this system throughout ; it is not only profitable to the Light Railways, but also to the Government Railways, which receive the greater proportion of the receipts. The Light Railway Companies whose stations number in the neighborhood of 300 are anxious to open them all to through-booking. The Government stations number about 250. I would suggest that this matter should be taken up, and that special notices should be distributed.

The chief cause of complaint against the companies has been the irregularity of trains, and it can be partly accounted for by the wet and slippery state of the agricultural roads during the rainy season. This can hardly be avoided while the railways follow so closely the agricultural roads, where there is a great deal of traffic and the rails get covered with the sticky mud and retard the trains. However, a marked improvement can be noted over the previous year, chiefly due to better supervision, more powerful engines, and the increase of separate trains for goods on lines where traffic is heaviest. The separation of passengers and goods is the only satisfactory arrangement. If they are handled jointly one or the other must suffer.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. FOOTNALL
div.p: ST. ANDREW V. D. Co. DUBLIN FUSILIERS.

The above teams met on Moharrem Bey common on Saturday last. This is the second meeting this season, the first game having guide to the "Dube" by 5 goals to 1. The Saints were rther under strength, but never theless the game was very evenly contested throughout, both defences having a lot to do. The "Dubs" were the first to score, the ball being rushed into the net by Leary after a misunderstanding between Davies and Curtis. Saints tried hard to eqalise before the close of the half and some good play by Constantinides brought the forwards well into the "Dubs" territory. Bright had hard lines in not scoring from a clearance by Nowland after the custodian had been hard pressed. All further attacks were repulsed and half-time arrived with the scores : D Co. 1 ; St Andrew nil.

The teams turned round without leaving the field and the second half opened briskly. The "Dubs" looked like increasing their lead from a brilliant individual effort by Coyne, who beat halves and backs alike, but with only Curtis to beat the shot over the bar. The Saints then got away on the right and Constantimidis took the ball well down, there placing to centre. Bright took it up and passed to Jones, who very smartly netted the ball. Being again on a level footing both teams tried their utmost to obtain the lead, but all efforts were fruitless and time arrived with the score one all. The following were the teams : --St. Andrew F.C.--Curtis, Hopkins, Davis, Mace, Cowie, Williams, Conatantinidis, Angel, Bright, Jones, and Tullock.
"Dubs" D Co. F.C.--Nowland, Henley, McMullen, Kavangh, Murray, Power, Brazil, McFadyen, Leay, Coyne, Kenny. Referee: Dowdall.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The General Administration of the Wakts informs the public that it possesses at Alexandria lands covering an area of about 18 feddans, situated on the bank of the El Farkhah Canal, part of which is occupied by small houses, belonging to the tenants.
To meet the desire of the public who wish to acquire these lands the Administration has placed them en adjudication twice, on the 4th November and 2nd inst.

Any one wishing to take part in this adjudication over L.E. 21,900 should apply at the offices of the Wakfs Delegation at Alexandria on Saturday, Januray 6, 1906, from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., to examine the list of lands and make his bid. Each application must be accompanied by a guarantee equal to 20% of the offer.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From our Financial Correspondent.)
The Monetary Position.
London, December 8.

The general feeling in the City is that whatever happens in Russia, things here cannot be greatly disturbed. The monetary position is thoroughly sound, speculative accounts are small and well in hand, and while everybody is naturally cautious, nothing is likely to happen to cause any kind of panic, even if the worst news came. Sometimes a state of tension from absence of news (as is the case with Russia to-day. St. Petersburg being satill practically cut off) is even worse than bad news, and the fact that the markets are quite cool is sufficient to indicate their being fully prepared for almost anything that might happen. In the case of a very serious fall in Russian securities, it is generally admitted that Germany is the weak spot. Not only have the German banks a considerable quantity of Russian bonds, but the German investor has absorbed a great many in recent times, and he is not in a position to make big losses, as it admitted that Germany is in a very poor condition financially, which is not improved by the announcement of the very heavy new taxes which the Government are about to levy.

Although Germany is the weakest point to-day, we do not think there is any serious catastrophe likely to happen in Berlin, and even should one occur, in consequence of disastrous news from Russia, it is doubtful if it would very seriously affect the position here. Money is unquestionably accumulating, and it is thought that very considerable sums are being brought from Russia for investment in this country, as is usual in times of panic abroad.

It is true that the Bank of England might have a larger reserve, but with a 4% rate and the proportion of reserve to liabilities 40.89%, it is quite satisfactory, and is comparatively even more favorable than last year with a rate 3% against 4% this year. While money is dear in New York-as much as 25% has been paid for day to day money-no apprehension need be felt, as the Secretary to the Treasury could at any time supply more than the market could possibly require, as the Treasury holds the enormous total of £148,000,000.

As against the absurd rates in New York, which, of course, are not applied except for Stock Exchange speculative transactions, London's day to day rate went down to 1% and there is every indication of continued ease. This is largely the result of the meturing of large amounts of Exchequer bons. With the discount houses reducing their deposit rates by 1%, the question of the reduction of Bank rate comes to the front, but this is not considered likely for the present. Four per cent. is a thoroughly wholesome rate for trade in its present active state, and it is highly improbable any change will be made in the present condition of political affairs.
Home Railways.

Outside the heavy fall in South Eastern and Chatham Railway stocks, due to the disastrous collapse of the roof of Charing Cross station, there has been nothing of any moment during in home securities. It is reckoned that the loss incurred by this accident, apart from the very great inconvenience to which it has put the large number of Continental and other travellers, will amount to a good half-a-million, and it seems to be doubted in some quarters whether the opportunity will not be seized to do away with this station altogether, which, with the bridge connected with it, is architecturally one of the greatest eyesores in the West of London. The shares have fallen to an extent that fully reflects this loss, and other railways have to a certain extent sympathised.
The Trade Return.

The Board of Trade returns just issued show a progressive increase in the exports of considerable magnitude, and the fact that this increase consists very largely of manufactured goods points to a condition of trade with which the fuss about the unemployed seems very much out of harmony. There is no doubt that this improvement in trade will be a strong card in the hands of the enemies of Mr. Chamberlain, and will probably have the effect of postponing Tariff Reform, at any rate for the present.
Consols
Since last week Consols have kept fairly steady, with an increase in price. They leave off to right at 89 7/8 ex-div., an advance of 7/8 on last Friday.
Foreign Bonds.

The increasing seriousness of the situation in Russia has naturally been reflected in the movements of Russian bonds, which have this week touched the lowest point since they were issued. There was a slight recovery on Wednesday under the influence of a statement made by M. Rouvier in the French Chamber to the effect that there would be sufficient funds to secure the payment of the interest for two or three years. This improvement has not, however, been maintained, and the bonds leave off to-night at 8 0 1/2-1, a fall on the week of 3 points.

Earlier in the week there was some selling of the new Japanese loan by applicants who had expected larger allotments, but the bonds generally are steady. The new loan is quoted to-night at 15/16 prem. special settlement, 11/16 for cash.
American Ralls.
The moderate tone of President Roosevelt's message to Congress has had a reassuring effect upon the American railway market, and an upward tendency prevails.
Egyptians.

In the Egyptian market the features have been the interest aroused by the Corporation of Western Egypt report, which would seem to bear out the forecast of the premoters of this important company, and the demand for the shares of the Egyptian Estates, whose manager is recognised as having shown himself exceptionally capable, and realised, as it is understood he has done, large profits for the company in so short a time, without apparently running any risks of importance. The shares have changed hands as high as 1 1/2, but have relapsed slightly to 1 3/8-7/16.

National Bank of Egypt rose sharply to 25 1/2 buyers, but close down again at 25 1/4. The new shares are quoted 4 1/2 premium. Agricultural Banks keep steady at 9 1/8-3/8, and the new issue at 83/4. Delta Preference remain at about 11 3/4, and Daira Ordinary and Deferred at 17 3/8-5/8 and 106-110 respectively, but no business is passing. Corporation of Western Egypt have been a good market at 5/8-3/4 premium, but close 9/14-11/16. Daira Sugar are uncertain at 4 1/4-3/4 on the approach of the declaration of the dividend, which is expected shortly Abyssinian Banks at about par, and Union Fonciere at 7/8 premium are quite unmentioned, although the market keeps steady at these prices. Egyptian Markets are nominally 1 1/4-3/8, and Salt and Soda 1-1/8. Land Bank of Egypt are 7 3/4- 8 1/4, with a very nominal market at this price.
Mining.
The mining market has been affected by the fears of a panic in Paris. South Africans were depressed in the early days of the week, but they have recovered, and close with a firmer tone.

The Egyptian section has again received little attention, and prices continue to droop. Nile Valley are 1/8 down at 5/8, and Um Rus are 1/16 lower at 5/8. Egyptian Mines are quoted 11s.6d, and Sudan Mines are unchanged at 1 5/8.
The closing prices tonight are as follows :--

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report.
Liverpool, December 7.

There has been very little improvement in the demand for Egyptians this week, prices however are 1/16 per lb. higher, except Fine Brown which is unchanged. In Futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the latest quotations :--
Dec. 8.19 Feb. 8.49 April 8.18 June 8.18
Jan. 8.19 Mar. 8.18 May 8.18 July 8.18

American Futures. The Market this week has been very active, an extensive business has been transacted daily and values have advanced 27 @ 30 points, of which about 4 points have been lost on a reaction. To-day's closing values are 23 @ 27 points higher than those of last Thursday. The chief feature of the week has of course been the Bureau Report, 10,167,000 bales. To this figure have to be added linters, cotton left voer from last season not brought into sight, and say 5% for the usual corrections, which would indicate a supply of 10 3/4 @ 11 million for the present season, plus the stocks at the ports and at the American interior towns, and in the hands of the consumers all the world over on the 31st August last, currently estimated at 2 million bales. This would appear to be a very ample supply, even allowing fully for the large consumption which it is believed will exceed that of last season, although if the present high range of values is to be maintained we doubt if it will reach such a figure. The South is "bull" and planters are apparently determined and able to control the supply and to command still higher prices in the immediate future, but we think the trade of the world will gradually be adversely affected as time goes on and that holders will not be able to realise the balance of this crop at such a high level of prices. The latest values are delivery:--
Dec. 6.31 Mar./Apr. 6.45 July/Aug. 6.54
Dec./Jan. 6.31 Apr./May 6.48 Aug./Sept. 6.47
Jan./Feb. 6.36 May/June 6.51 Sept./Oct. 6.14
Feb./Mar. 6.40 June/July 6.53 Oct./Nov. 6.05

div.head: TO COMPETE WITH EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: The Oceana Consolidated Company, Limited, have, it is stated by a London contemporary, recently sold in Liverpool a first consignment of 318 bales of cotton grown on their plantation at Chiromo, British Central Africa, at an average price of 8d- per pound. The cotton was grown from seed imported from Egypt, and the company's brokers (Messrs. Wolstenholme and Holland) report that if the plantation continues to produce quality equal to these early shipments they will be enabled to compete with Egyptian cotton.

div.head: OSTRICH FEATHER SALES.
div.p: These sales commenced in London on the 2nd inst. and concluded on the 5th. The quantity on offer was larger than at the October sales, the total being 83,400 lb. against 69,500 lb. in October, and 75,000 lb. December, 1904. Of this 8,429 lb. was Egyptian, which compared with 9,275 lb. at the last sale.
The attendance was large, and there was a good demand throughout. Prices, with a few exceptions, were higher than at the October auctions.
Egyptian sold well, and out of the 230 cases offered, 211 were sold, realising £6,571. The total amount of the sales was £173,000.

div.head: GOLD EXPORTS FROM EGYPT.
div.p: (From our Financial Correspondent).
London, December 8.

We hear of £200,000 in gold being shipped from Alexandria to India. There is an expectation in money circles here that considerable shipments of gold may be expected from Egypt. We fear this hope is doomed to be a disappointed one. During 1904 the exports of bullion from London to Egypt amounted to £4,632,000, but up to October this year Egypt appears to have taken in gold, silver, bullion, and specie about £2,000,000 short of this amount. It is doubtful whether, considering the large profits which have been made by the growers in Egypt, any further substantial amount of gold will find its way back here, beyond a few hundred thousand pounds.

The exports from Egypt last year, notwithstanding the above large imports, were comparatively trifling, and up to the end of October of the present year only about £270,000 had reached the United Kingdom from Egypt.

The money market must realise the fact that Egypt, like India, will be like a leech, in absorbing the precious metals for some time to come. Fortunately, the world's supplies of both gold and silver are so large, that what might have been a serious factor in the monetary situation a few years ago is not now likely to have any effect.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound.
TO OUR VISITORS.
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe. This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily. Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:--
The long sea routes--from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southampton, London or Liverpool--occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows :--
Port Said or Alexandria to Brindisi : 3 days
Alexandria to Messina : 3 days
Port Said or Alexandria to Marseilles : 5 days
Alexandria to Venice and Trieste : 4 days
Alexandria to Naples : 3 days
Port Said to Genoa : 5 days
Port Said to Naples : 4 days
Alexandria to Constantinople : 4 days
Alexandria to Piraeus : 2 days
Port Said to Gibraltar : 7 days

The steamers, of the P. and O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P. and O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste-Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry boats," having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: PISA GRAND HOTEL ET HOTEL DE LONDRES
SICILY
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMINA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour.In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain - his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay--Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cogwheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made, in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient halfway house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba)--The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature--warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn to Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Nilan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Dorino and in half an hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: Gnd HOTEL DE LA VILLE, FLORENCE.
NORTHERN ITALY and THE ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage, or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other seaport. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going nothwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot ; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two and three quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one and a half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate, and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and "The Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE--A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc. are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

A delightful excursion from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand ; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhosn.

THE BERNESE OBERLAND.--INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbach, and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of the Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft. above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE AND IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of he Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
